dialogueHeader.title: JOHN AMBROSE
dialogueHeader.author: unknown
dialogueHeader.contemporaneity: Source text dates from same year as the first printing / original speech event

textBibliography.frontMatter: MINUTES TAKEN AT THE COURT-MARTIAL, HELD UPON CAPTAIN JOHN AMBROSE, ON BOARD THE LONDON, ON THE 18, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 28, 29, AND 31 OCTOBER, AND 1, 4, 5, 6, AND 7TH OF NOVEMBER 1745. BEING AN ENQUIRY INTO THE CONDUCT OF THE SAID GENTLEMAN IN THE LATE ENGAGEMENT IN THE MEDITERRANEAN. WITH CUTS. LONDON: PRINTED FOR M. COOPER, IN PATERNOSTER-ROW, 1745. PP. 42.21 - 70.44

dialogue.comment: SINGLE CLOSING SQUARE BRACKETS USED FOR PARENTHETICAL COMMENTS BY NARRATOR ARE OMITTED.

dialogueText.head: SECOND DAY.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Chatham , Ship London , October the 21st , 1745.

nonSpeech.font: The Court ordered the Marshal to bring in the Prisoner.

dialogueText.nonSpeech: Captain JOHN AMBROSE brought into Court .

Lieutenant Hugh Palliser was called in and sworn. Then his Deposition was read, setting forth, that he was first Lieutenant of the Essex , during the Month of February 1743; which Ship, on the 11th of the said Month, was stationed next a-stern of the Dorsetshire and the third a-stern of the Admiral in the Engagement off Toulon ; that the Dorsetshire and Rupert bore down when the Admiral did, but not so near as the Admiral and Marlbro' , nor near enough to form the Line; that the Dorsetshire began to engage soon after the Admiral, but he believes not within Point-blank; that the Fireship bore down, and pass'd by in sight of the Dorsetshire , Rupert ,
and Royal Oak , and that they then were to windward of the Line, and might have conducted and covered her, but none of them did; that the Marlbro' was disabled, and that the Dorsetshire , Essex , and Rupert were then to windward; and that the Rupert , if she had pass'd by the Dorsetshire , might have assisted the Marlbro' , and might have covered the Fireship.
dialogueText.dialogue: Is this Deposition true?
Yes.
Was the Rupert never in the Line?
No.
Was she ever within Point-blank?
No, not when I saw her.
What time did you see her?
I saw her several times that Day.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
Yes.
Did the Rupert attempt to cover her?
No.
Did she ever attempt to cover the Marlbro' ?
She went down to the Marlbro' at Night, when we wore, but not before.
Was she near you when you brought up?
Yes, she presently fell farther a-stern of us and to leeward, but not so far as to form the Line.
Was she ever within Point-blank?
No.
What time was the Royal Oak engaged with the three Spanish Ships?
I cannot tell.
Do you remember any thing of the Royal Oak and Rupert driving away the first Ship they engaged before the Wind?
No, I never saw any of the Spanish Ships a-stern of their Admiral, but before the Wind.
Did you see the Royal Oak engage them?
Yes.
Where was the Rupert then?
To windward of the Royal Oak .
How far to windward?
A long Mile from, but not so far to windward.
Was the Rupert then engag'd?
No, the Rupert was then farther from the Enemy than the Royal Oak by a Mile.
When did you see the Royal Oak engaged?
I believe an Hour after the Admiral began.
Was there any Ship for you to engage at first?
Yes, if we had gone into our Station.
When you haul'd your Wind was there any Ship before your Beam?
No.
Did the Rupert bear away before the Admiral wore?
Yes.
How long before?
I can't tell exactly.
Was she in a Line with the Namur then?
I can't say; she was not so far to Leeward as the Admiral was when he began to engage.
Was the Namur considerably to windward of the Marlborough then?
Yes.
When was that?
Just before the Admiral made the Signal and wore.
How much before?
About half an Hour.
Was the Rupert firing then?
Yes.
Was she within Gun-shot?
No.
What time was that?
When she bore away, half an Hour before the Admiral wore.
Was she then engaging briskly?
Yes.
Did you ever see the Royal Oak engage within Point-blank?
She was pretty near it.
Was it in the Rupert's Power to have gone down with her?
Yes, I saw nothing to hinder her.
Was the Rupert any way disabled?
No, she cou'd not be disabled, because she had had no Engagement before that.
When you saw the Rupert firing smartly, where was the headmost of the five of the Enemy coming up in respect of the Rupert ?
It was when one or two of the headmost Ships fired at the Fireship, and they were then shot past the Rupert .
How was the Rupert then in respect to you?
Abreast of us, half a Mile nearer the Enemy.
Did you fire a Gun then?
Yes.
What time of the Day was it?
About four.
Did your Shot fall short?
Yes.
Was the Rupert then half a Mile nearer the Enemy than you?
Yes.
Did the Enemy return any Shot to you?
No.
Did any Shot go over the Rupert ?
Not at that time; when we wore there did.

If the Rupert and Royal Oak had engaged those Ships as closely as they ought to have done, wou'd they have stopped
those Ships from annoying ours, and hinder'd SOURCE TEXT: hinder d them from getting up till the Vice-Admiral's Division had got up?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Here the Prisoner interrupted, and said, he apprehended that was not a proper Question.
The Court said ,
dialogueText.dialogue: We have a Right to ask any Questions we think fit, and you are at liberty to ask any Question you think proper, and we have shewn you a particular Indulgence in that respect.

We wou'd have attack'd them with five of our Ships, that is, the Essex , Rupert , Royal Oak , Dunkirk , Cambridge ; but I can't say whether the Rupert and Royal Oak only cou'd have stop'd them SOURCE TEXT: then .
Were the Dunkirk , or Cambridge near enough to attack them?
If they had gone into their Station, they would have been near enough.
Did you ever see the Hercules go near to assist the Ship attack'd by the Rupert and Royal Oak ?
No.
Did you see any Shot go over the Rupert ?
Not till we wore.
What distance was the headmost from the Dunkirk , and Cambridge from the Royal Oak ?
I can't tell.
Did you ever see the Cambridge bear under the Royal Oak's Stern?
Yes, just before we wore, and she fired at the Enemy under the Royal Oak's starboard Quarter.
When you saw the Cambridge under the Royal Oak's Stern, where was the Rupert ?
This was just before we wore, she was then firing at the Enemy.
Do you remember, when the Admiral wore, how many of the four or five Sail of the Enemy had past before the Rupert's Beam?
I can't tell exactly.
You was a-head and could see.
I don't remember whether any of them open'd a-head of the Rupert .
Was any of them a-head of you?
When I fired a Shot, I don't remember whether the two headmost were a-head or a-stern of the Rupert .
Was the Rupert then directly to leeward of you?

Yes, half a Mile nearer the Enemy, it cou'd not be more, because of our wearing soon after, and we had not Room to wear short of her, but soon fell on board of her, which obliged us to shift our Helm, by which we were jostled
down very near the Enemy; the Fire from the Muzzel of our Guns set her Spritsail on fire.
Was the Rupert directly a-breast of you then?
Yes.
How was the Admiral in respect of you when the Rupert was a-breast of you?
Upon our Lee-Bow.
Was the Rupert between you and the Enemy when you fired?
Yes, I fired two single Shot from our lower Deck, with the Guns laid down in the Carriage, both which I saw fall short.
Did the five of the Enemy continue their Course under the same Sail?
Yes.
Supposing the Rupert had bore down in a Line with the Admiral, and brought up in a Line when he did, how long would it have been before the Rupert would have had any Ship to engage?
If the Rupert had gone down and brought up in a Line with the Admiral, she would have been in a proper Position to engage the five Sail of the Enemy coming up.
Did the Rupert stop those Ships from getting up?
No, I believe not.
From the beginning of the Engagement till the Admiral wore, did you ever observe the Rupert annoy the Enemy in any Shape whatever?
No, she fired a good deal, but not within a Distance to do Execution.
Did you see any Shot of the Enemy come over the Rupert , when she was a-breast of you?
No.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
Yes.
Did any of the Enemy fire at her?
The headmost of the five Sail did.
Was the Rupert within Gun-shot of them then?
No.
Was the Essex ?
No.
Was the Essex always to windward of the Rupert ?
Yes.
Did any Shot of the Enemy reach you?
Yes, at first.
How was the Rupert off you then?
To leeward of us.
Did you from the time the Shot reach'd you, continue SOURCE TEXT: cotinue hauling off?
Yes.
Did the Rupert haul off too?
Yes.
What was the meaning of your hauling off?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Witness made no Answer, but smiled, so did the Court.
dialogueText.dialogue: Had you received any Damage, or had the Rupert ?
No.
Did the Rupert continue hauling off?
Yes, till she bore away again, and begun to fire briskly in the Evening.
How long was it from the Rupert's first bearing up, till she bore down again?
I never saw that she bore away again from the Beginning, till half an Hour before the Admiral wore.
Did you ever see the Rupert had received any Damage to prevent her going into her Station?
No, at no time of the Day.
In the Evening, when you wore, did not you engage the five Spanish Ships a-stern, and how was it possible, if once they got a-head of the Rupert , for the Rupert to wear and engage them in passing?
The Rupert had bore away, and was firing at those Ships upon the Admiral's wearing; it was then that I observed the Rupert .
If the five Ships once past me, how could I go under the Stern of the Admiral and all the other Ships, and engage those five Ships in passing?
They were not a-breast of you when you fired at them.

You say that I was engaged with the five Ships, that I was half a Mile from you, and that I was out of point-blank, then how could I shoot up to you in the Wearing, and engage the five Ships in passing?
You did not shoot up to us, we came down to you.
Did you ever see the Royal-Oak engage a single Ship?
No.
How far were the five Ships of the Enemy from you when the Admiral first engaged?
Three Miles, as near as I can judge, not so far a-stern, rather upon our lee-quarter.
How many Ships were there a-stern of the Hercules ?
Five.
What Sail had the five Ships out?
I can't say particularly, the two headmost had all their Sails set.
Did they all come up in a Line?
They appeared to me so.
How did they bear from you then, and how did your Head lye?
We were lying to, close to the Wind, and they were right a-stern of us by springing our Luff from them.
Did the Royal Oak fire before the Rupert ?
Yes.
Were the Royal-Oak and Rupert firing together at the same Time?
Yes, in the Evening, when you was firing briskly.
As the Rupert was between you and the Enemy, how could you distinguish whether I was near enough to do Execution?

I could judge of the Distance as it appeared to me, and by our Shot falling short by the Distance you were from us, and the Distance we were from the Enemy; I think we in the Essex were two Miles from them, and you half a Mile nearer than we.
Then I was a Mile and a half off?
Yes.
From the Situation you lay to windward, could you judge whether the Rupert was in a Line with the Admiral?
Yes, because you was so near us, therefore I am sure you was not in a Line.
If the Rupert had gone down in a proper Line at first, would there have been any Ship for her to engage?

If you had continued going down with an easy Sail till you had compleated the Line from the Namur , I judge you would have fell in a-breast of the Headmost Ship of the Five; for the Royal Oak , by continuing her Course down, fell a-breast of the Second; a little more of her Port-helm in going down, would have laid her along-side of the Third, you might have taken the Second, and we in the Essex the First.
If I had gone down to the Headmost of the Five Ships, how far should I have been from you, supposing you had gone in the Line?
At a proper Distance; a Quarter of a Mile.
How was the Hercules from the other three Ships?

Three Miles the most at first; but had you gone down with an easy Sail, as that Space was growing less and less, when you had got down so far as to be in a Line, you would have been a-breast of the Headmost of those Ships.
Was you far out of your Station at your first bringing to?
No.
Then how could I have any Ship to engage?
But we were a great Way from the Enemy when that Shot reached us; I judge the Essex's Distance from the Hercules was about two Miles, and her Weather Guns would carry a Shot that Distance.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Court interrupted, and told the Prisoner, that the asking those Questions took up a great deal of Time, and only seem'd proper Questions to be ask'd his own Witnesses. The Prisoner said, he thought them material; but if the Court thought they were not proper Questions, he would submit.
dialogueText.dialogue: Do you think in the Situation I was in, if the five Sail of the Enemy had held their Course they first steer'd, could they have fetch'd me?
No, they steer'd for their Admiral; if they had kept their Wind close, they might have fetch'd you.
Did you wear a-head or a-stern of the five Spanish Ships in the Rear, when you wore?
We wore and past a-stern of them; when we wore they were put before the Wind.
Did you engage them as you past?
We engaged with our Larboard Guns when we wore.

nonSpeech.font: Then the Prisoner addressed himself to the Court.

dialogueText.dialogue: As all these Gentlemen have been already examined, and cross-examined upon former Tryals, it will be impossible for me to find out any Mistakes they are guilty of; and therefore I would beg of every Gentleman that is a Member of the Court, to destroy the Minutes they have taken upon the former Tryals, that they may have no Influence in regard to the Sentence that may be pass'd upon my Conduct.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Captain Renton , one of the Members of the Court, said,
dialogueText.dialogue: I believe every Gentleman that is a Member of the Court, will not only destroy the Minutes taken upon former Tryals, but endeavour to forget as much as possible, every thing that has pass'd upon former Tryals.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Prisoner said ,
dialogueText.dialogue: I mention this, not that I have the least Suspicion of the Court, but because I hope to prove that you never yet had a right understanding of the Matter.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The President said ,
dialogueText.dialogue: You are not to dictate to the Court; every Body here are Persons of Honour, and will do you Justice; and therefore I think that Speech of yours very ungenteel.
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
Then Lieutenant Joseph Peyton of the Essex was called in and sworn, and his Deposition read, setting forth, That he was fourth Lieutenant of the Essex , on the 11th of February 1743, which Ship was station'd the next a-stern of the Dorsetshire , and the third a-stern of the Admiral; that in the Morning a Signal was
made for a Line a-head, and about one the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal-Oak bore down when the Admiral did, but not near enough to form the Line; that between three and four the Ann Galley Fireship bore down in Sight of the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal Oak , and that they were not then engaged; that the Marlborough was disabled, having her Main and Mizen-Masts shot away; and that the Essex was to windward of the Rupert , and the Rupert to windward of the Royal Oak ; that they were all to windward of the Line the greatest Part of the Engagement; and that if they had bore down as the Admiral and Marlborough did, they might have cover'd the Fireship, and kept the Sternmost Ships of the Enemy from getting up till the Vice Admiral and his Division had got up.
dialogueText.dialogue: Did the Rupert haul up to windward of the Admiral?
Yes.
Did she fire?
Yes, between three and four.
At what Ship?
At the Sternmost Ships coming up.
Was she within point-blank?
No, I think not.
Did you see the Marlbro' when her Masts went away?
Yes.
Did the Rupert assist her?
No.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
Yes.
Where was the Rupert then?
To windward.
Did she cover the Fireship?
No, not that I saw.
Did you ever see the Rupert in the Line?
No, I don't know how she might have been in the Evening.
Did you ever see the Rupert within point-blank, from the Beginning of the Engagement till the Admiral wore?
No.
If she had gone within point-blank, would she have been to leeward of the Namur ?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Witness asked ,
dialogueText.dialogue: At what Time?
When the Headmost of the five Ships came up?
I can't judge.
How far was you to windward of the Line?
A good Way; three Quarters of a Mile, or more.
How far was the Rupert to leeward of you?
Two Cables length and a half.
What Time did you observe the Rupert fire smartly?
Between three and four.
What Ship did she fire at?
At the five Sail coming up.
At which of them?
Faith I can't tell.
Did you ever observe the five Sail pass before the Beam of the Rupert ?
I can't tell whether they did or no.
Did they ever alter their Course, or shorten Sail when they fired at any of our Ships?
No, our Ships were at too great a Distance for that.
Was there Wind sufficient for the Rupert to have gone down near enough to have engaged them properly?
Yes.
When the Rupert made a warm Fire, did any of the Enemy's Shot come over her?
No.
Did you see any of them fall short?
No.
Did you see the Royal Oak fire?
Yes.
Did you see the Rupert then?
I must have seen her.
How far was the Rupert to windward of the Royal-Oak ?
Two Cables length.
To windward or a-head?
Upon her Weather-bow, to windward and a-head.
Was she as much farther from the Enemy?
Yes.
When you fired the Guns from your Ship, could you see the Rupert ?
No.
When you haul'd your Wind, did the Rupert do so too?
I can't be positive; I did not observe; but when the Marlbro's Masts were gone, she was to windward.
During what Time did you see the Rupert ?
I was most of the Time upon the Quarter-deck SOURCE TEXT: Quarter-dec k and must have seen her often.
At what Ship did you fire your Guns?
At the Hercules .
Did you fire any at the Sternmost Spanish Ships?
No.
When you haul'd off, did the Rupert do so too?
I can't say.
Did you observe the Rupert bear down nearer than you at first?
Yes.
Did she ever bear down nearer than that?
Not till the Admiral wore.
Did the Shot reach you from the Enemy?
Yes, at the first of the Engagement.
Was the Rupert the next Ship to you?
Yes.
If the Rupert had bore down at first, might not she have engaged the Hercules ?
It was in her Power, there was Wind enough.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then the Prisoner said , He had a great many Questions to ask, if the Court thought proper.
The Court said , He might ask what Questions he pleased.
dialogueText.dialogue: How long did you keep firing at the Hercules ?
Till after the Marlbro's Masts were gone.
Did your Shot reach?
I think not.
Did their Shot reach you?
Yes, at first; but we kept hauling off; and when the Marlbro' lost her Masts we left off firing.
Was there any Ship for the Rupert to engage, if she had come down at first?
Not unless she had gone to the Hercules .
Was the Dorsetshire firing upon the Hercules ?
She fired sometimes.
If you had commanded the Rupert , do you think it would not have been better to have engaged the Ships coming up, than to have gone to engage the Hercules and assist the Marlbro' ?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Court said ,
dialogueText.dialogue: That was not a proper Question, we can best judge of that.
Did you see any of my Shot fall short?
No, I never saw any.
Were the five Sail coming up, to leeward of their Admiral?
I believe, rather to leeward, but very little.
When you saw the Rupert and Royal Oak engaging, were they to leeward of the Admiral and Marlbro' ?
No.
Were they near one another?
No.
If the Spanish Ships had held the Course they came up when the Rupert and Royal Oak were engaging them, could not they have weather'd the Rupert ?
I believe they could have gone very near to have done it.
As the Rupert was at first under your Lee-quarter, how came she afterwards to be so far to leeward of you; was it by your hauling off, or her bearing away?
I can't judge of that.
Was the Rupert engaging the five Sail, and between them and the Fireship, when the Fireship blew up?
She was not immediately between them.
Was the Rupert a-head stemming for the Fireship, when the Fireship blew up?
I can't say.
Was the Rupert nearer the Fireship than the five Ships?
They were nearer when the Fireship blew up.
Did they pass me?
I can't say.
As these Ships came up to annoy the Fireship, I must have stop'd them?
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Court said , This was argumentative, and no Answer was given to it.
dialogueText.dialogue: When the Rupert was engaging those Ships, were they upon her Quarter, or upon her Beam?
Rather upon her Quarter.
I think you say my Shot fell short?
I did not say so.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then Lieutenant Hamilton Gore of the Essex was called in and sworn, and his Deposition read, setting forth, That he was a Lieutenant on board the Essex in the Month of February 1743, which Ship, on the 11th of the same Month was station'd next a-stern of the Dorsetshire , and the Third a-stern of the Admiral; that the Dorsetshire , Rupert and Royal Oak bore down towards the Enemy, as the Admiral did, but not near enough to form the Line, tho' they might have done it, having Wind sufficient; that the Fireship passed by in Sight of the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal Oak , not covered or conducted by any of the other Ships; that they might have done it, but did not; that the Marlbro' was disabled, having her Main and Mizen-mast shot away; that the Essex was then to windward of all the Ships a-stern; the Rupert was to windward of the Royal Oak ; that they all kept to windward of the Line during the greatest Part of the Engagement; that if they had come down they might have covered the Fireship, and stopt the Sternmost Ships of the Enemy from coming up, till the Vice-Admiral and his Division had got up.
dialogueText.dialogue: Where was you quartered?
Upon the lower Gun-deck.
Did you see the Rupert when she first haul'd up?
Yes.
Was she in a Line with the Admiral?
No, to windward.
Did you ever see the Rupert engaged?
Yes, she fired.
At what Time was it?
A little after the Admiral did.
At what Ship did she fire?
I took it to be the Hercules .
At what Distance?
A Mile and a half, or better.
Did you see the Marlbro' when her Masts went away?
Yes.
Did the Rupert assist her?
No.
When the Fireship bore away, did the Rupert assist her, or cover her from the Enemy?
No.
Was she never within point-blank?
Not till we wore.
Did you ever see the Rupert in a Line with the Admiral?
No.
How do you know she was not in a Line with the Admiral?
Because I saw both her and the Admiral.
Was you in the Line?
No.
How far to windward of the Line?
A Mile.
How far was the Rupert from you?
Better than a Quarter of a Mile.
Was the Rupert a Quarter of a Mile to leeward or a-stern of you?
To leeward.
Could the Rupert have engaged the Hercules if she had bore down properly?
To be sure.
Was there any Ship between the Rupert and Marlbro' , to take up the Hercules ?
The Dorsetshire was between, but she was to windward.
If the Rupert had bore down to the Hercules , must not she have shot a-head of the Dorsetshire and Essex ?
Yes, but they were to leeward.
At the first of the Action, if the Rupert had bore down and brought up in a Line, was there any Ship for her to engage?
She might have engaged if she had gone to the Marlbro's Assistance.
If she had brought up in a Line with the Admiral, cou'd she have engaged?
No.
If she had brought up at first, could she have brought any of her Guns upon the Hercules ?
Yes, she did fire at the Hercules .
Had she gone down nearer, cou'd she have engaged the Hercules properly?
Yes.

If the Rupert had bore down in a proper Line, and kept there; how long wou'd it have been before the headmost of the Spanish Ships could have come up within Gun-shot of her, supposing they cou'd have crowded sail?
Half an Hour, or three quarters of an Hour.
Did she fire at the Hercules ?
Yes.
When these Ships came up, was the Rupert in a proper station SOURCE TEXT: t ation to engage the headmost of them?
No, she fired, and her Shot all fell short.
Did you see them fall short?
Yes, both the Enemy's and hers fell short; the Enemy's fell nearer the Rupert , than the Rupert's did the Enemy.
When you first brought up, what distance was you from the Dorsetshire ?
Better than a quarter of a Mile.
How was the Dorsetshire from you?
To leeward.
How was the Rupert then?
In a Line with the Dorsetshire .
During any part of the Day before the Admiral wore, were the five Sail shot a-head of the Rupert ?
No.
Did the Essex haul her Wind?
Yes.
Did any of the five Sail shorten Sail or alter their Course from the Fire of any of our Ships?
No, none of them a-stern did.
Was you in a Line with the Namur when she was haul'd off toward the latter part of the Action?
No, never.
If the Rupert had brought up in a Line, wou'd she have been within Point-blank of the Enemy?
Yes.
If the Rupert had haul'd up in a Line with the Admiral, where wou'd the headmost of the five Sail have been from her?
Within Point-blank.
Did you ever see the five sail pass the Rupert ?
No.
Did the Rupert bring up when the Admiral did?
Yes.
Are you sure that the Rupert did not keep bearing down after the Admiral haul'd up?
I think he brought up then.
Did the Rupert bring up when the Admiral did?
Yes SOURCE TEXT: Ye .
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then the Court observ'd, every Ship must be in a Consternation, when the Admiral brought up.
dialogueText.dialogue: Did you take notice of the Enemy's Ships, a short time before the Admiral wore?
Yes.
How many of them had pass'd the Beam of the Rupert ?
I think they all had pass'd
When the Admiral wore, had any of the Enemy's shot before the Beam of the Rupert ?
They had shot up nearer their Admiral.
How many of them?
All the five.
Were they all nearer the Fireship than the Rupert was?
I think they were.
When the Admiral wore, were the five Ships a-breast, a-head, or a-stern of the Rupert ?
I believe a-breast of her.
If I had bore down with the Admiral at first, and brought up in a Line, how long wou'd it have been before the five Sail wou'd have been within Gun-shot?
Three quarters of an Hour.
How long must I have been in going into a Line with the Admiral, if I had put the Helm a-weather, after I had brought up?
Half an Hour, or better.
When he had got there, wou'd there have been any Ship for him to engage?
Yes, he must have been within Point-blank of the sternmost Ship.
If I had not brought to when I did, how long wou'd it have been before I had got into the Line?
Half an Hour.
Did any of the Enemy's Shot reach you?
Not that I saw.
When the Half Hour that you speak of my getting into the Line was expir'd, should I have been within Point-blank of any Ship?
Yes.
Did I fire at the Hercules when I brought to?
Yes, but the other Ships were a great way from their Admiral.
Did any of the five Sail pass the Rupert ?
I think they shot up when the Fireship bore down.
How far was the Hercules from the Ships coming up at the first of the Engagement?
I cannot say.
Were there four or five Ships coming up?
Five.
Did you see a single Spanish Ship, or any Ship engage her?
No.
SOURCE TEXT: A. Did I bring to to leeward of you?
Yes.
Was I in a Line with the Dorsetshire ?
It was as much as you were.
How far was you from me?
Not a great Way then, but we filled our Sails and hauled our Wind.
What did I do then?
You were firing.
What did I do at first?
You were firing.
When did you see my Shot fall short?
I saw it always fall short.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then Joseph Meyers of the Essex was called in and sworn. His Deposition read, setting forth, that he was Master of the Essex during the Month of February 1743; that about nine in the Morning of the 11th of the said Month Admiral Mathews made the Signal for the Line of Battle a-head, and that the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal Oak were in the Center Division, and stationed a-stern of the Admiral; that they bore down a little when the Admiral did, but not near enough to be in their Stations, and that the Royal Oak was to leeward of the others, and that they had all Wind enough to have gone nearer; that the Marlbro's Masts were shot away by the Enemy, and that the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal Oak were capable of assisting her, but did not; that between four and five the Ann Galley Fireship bore down, and was not covered or conducted by any of the other Ships; and that the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal Oak might have covered her, but they did not, as appeared to this Witness.
dialogueText.dialogue: Is this Deposition true?
Yes.
Did the Rupert haul up before she came in the Line?
Yes.
Did you ever see her engage within Point-blank?
Not till the Evening, when she wore.
Did you see when the Marlbro' lost her Masts?
Yes.
Did the Rupert give her any Assistance?
No.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
Yes.
Did the Rupert cover her or attempt it?
No.
What did the Rupert do?
She began to fire when we did.
When did she begin?
Soon after the Admiral.
At what Ship did she fire?
I cannot say; either at the Hercules , or the Ship a-stern.
What did she do after that?
She continued firing some time, and all the Shot fell short.
At what distance was she from the Enemy?
Not within Point-blank.
If she had gone down at first, was there Room for her to engage?
She must have gone a-head of us, there was nothing to hinder her.
If she had gone into her proper Station a-stern of the Admiral, would she have gone to engage the Hercules ?
Yes, a-head of us.
Supposing she had left a Space for the Essex and Dorsetshire , wou'd she then have done Execution upon the Hercules ?
No, she must then have engaged the headmost of the five Sail coming up then; but she might have brought some Guns to bear upon the Hercules .
SOURCE TEXT: A. If the Rupert had gone down in the Line at first, cou'd she have fired at the headmost of the five Sail of the Enemy, and left a Space for the Dorsetshire and Essex ?
Yes.
At the Beginning?
Yes.
Must not she have been to leeward of the Admiral then?
No.
When the Admiral wore in the Evening, what Position were the sternmost of the Enemy in from the Rupert ?
When the Admiral wore, we were firing at them.
Did they shoot up a-head, or lie a-breast of the Rupert ?
The headmost of them was upon her Beam, but not the sternmost.
Were they a-head of the Rupert ?
No, when we wore, we fired our larboard Guns at them.
When you was so near the Rupert , how far was you from the Spanish Ships?
Near a Mile.
Did any of the Spanish Ships coming up alter their Course from the Rupert's Fire?
No.
SOURCE TEXT: A. Was the Rupert never nearer the Spanish Ships than she was just before you wore?
No, that was the nearest.
Did you fire any Shot at the Enemy?
Yes.
At what Distance?
A Mile.
Why do you think so, did the Shot fall short?
Yes.
Was the Rupert ever in a Line with the Namur after she hauled off?
I cannot say.
Was you in the Essex ever as far to leeward as the Namur ?
No.
Was the Rupert ?
No.
How near was you to the Admiral before you wore?
A Mile and a quarter at nearest.
How far was the Rupert from you?
Between a quarter and half a Mile.
Was that the nearest you was to the Rupert before you wore?
Yes.
Did you ever see the headmost of the five Spanish Ships fire at the Fireship?
Yes.
Did their Shot reach?
Yes, they went both a-head and a-stern of her before they wore.
Were the five Ships to leeward of the Admiral?
I cannot say, because we were so far to windward.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Prisoner said,
dialogueText.dialogue: I have no more Questions to ask him now, but desire he may be in the Way lest I should have Occasion to call him in my Defence.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: The Court told the Witness,
dialogueText.dialogue: You are to attend till this Tryal is over:
dialogueText.nonSpeech: But upon Recollection, the President said, there wou'd be no End, if they suffer'd a Witness to be called more than once, and desired that the Prisoner would ask him what Questions he had to ask now.

The Judge-Advocate acquainted the Court, that he had known frequently that a Witness has been called in three or four times, and that he had himself seen it, and therefore it was determined that he had Liberty to call him again when he thought proper.

Then Lieutenant Edmund Turner of the Royal Oak was called in and sworn, and his Deposition read, setting
forth, that he was Lieutenant of the Royal Oak on the 11th of February 1743, and that about half past twelve the Admiral and Marlborough began to fire at the Enemy; and that all the Captains a-stern of the Admiral were in sight of the Signal to engage, and of the Engagement, and that the Rupert was half a Mile to winward of the Royal Oak ; and that after Captain Williams had ordered them to cease firing, because of our being too far off, he heard the Captain say twice,
dialogueText.dialogue: Why don't they bear down,
dialogueText.nonSpeech: meaning the Rupert and Essex .
dialogueText.dialogue: Is this Deposition true?
Yes.
Where was you quarter'd?
Upon the Gun-deck.
When the Royal Oak began to engage, how was the Rupert from her?
Half a Mile upon her Weather-bow.
Did she fire?
I did not see her fire.
Did you ever see the Rupert out of your Weather-Ports?
I was abaft the main Mast, and saw the Rupert out of the Weather-Ports, and our People cryed out; Look! Look! at the Essex and Rupert.
After the Royal Oak fired, where was the Rupert ?
I saw her to windward; I looked out now and then, and always saw her to windward.
Did you see her engage?
No.
How often did you look out?
Three or four Times.
During what space of Time?
An Hour.
Did you see the Rupert to windward of you then?
Yes.
Did you see when the Marlborough's Masts went away?
No.
Did you see her after?
Yes.
SOURCE TEXT: Qr Did the Rupert bear down to assist her?
I did not see that she did.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
No.
When you had done engaging the Spanish Ships, what did the Rupert do?
I can't say.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Sir Charles Molloy , one of the Members, said,
dialogueText.dialogue: This Witness says nothing;
dialogueText.nonSpeech: upon which the President said,
dialogueText.dialogue:
What
do you mean by saying he has said nothing? he says, he saw the Rupert to windward of the Royal Oak ,
dialogueText.nonSpeech: and ordered the Judge-Advocate to read what he had said, which was done accordingly.
dialogueText.dialogue: Did you ever see the Rupert in a Line with the Admiral?
I cannot tell the Situation, I was quartered below.
What Ship did you fire at in the Royal Oak ?
The headmost of the four.
How many of those Ships past by you?
I believe all of them but the last.
Just before you wore, did you SOURCE TEXT: yout look out at the Rupert ?
No.
Did you see the Spanish Ships then?
Yes.
How far were they shot a-head of you?
But a little Way.
Did they continue the same Sail as before?
Yes.
Did they alter their Course?
Not that I observed.
What Sail had they set?
Foresails, Topsails, and Top-gallant-sails; at the first of the Engagement some of them had their Top-gallant-sails lowered, and some not.
Which of them did you engage last?
They headmost of the four.
Was she before your Beam when you engaged her?
No, I think she was abaft the Beam.
Did you observe the Rupert then?
No.
Do you think they could have pass'd the Rupert ?
I cannot say.
Did you go upon Deck, before you wore Ship?
Not just before.
At the Time of the Wearing?
No, when I was ordered to cease firing, then I went up and saw the Situation of the Rupert .
From the Time the Engagement began till the Admiral wore, was the Rupert ever at a proper Distance from the Enemy to do Execution and engage?
I never saw her fire at all.
Did you ever see her at a proper Distance to do Execution?
I cannot say; she was upon our Weather-bow, but she might be within proper Execution.
Was you then at a proper Distance from the Enemy?
I cannot tell.
Was the Rupert always to windward of you?
Yes.
Did you see the Fireship come down?
No.
Do you know any thing of the Royal Oak's hailing the Rupert ?
No, nothing but what I heard afterwards.
Did you hear the Royal Oak hail the Rupert ?
No.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then Lieutenant Robert Wilson of the Royal Oak was called in and sworn.
dialogueText.dialogue: Where was you quartered?
Upon the upper Deck.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then his Deposition was read, setting forth, that he was first Lieutenant of the Royal-Oak the 11th of February 1743; that about one, the Namur and Marlbro' bore down, and engaged the Real and her Second a-stern; that the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal-Oak , were in sight of the Signal to engage, and of the Engagement; that the Royal-Oak was in a Line with the Admiral during the Engagement, but not with the Marlbro' , and he then saw the Rupert upon the Royal-Oak's Weather-Bow; that the Royal-Oak fired about twelve, but she was not in a Line with the Marlbro' ; that Capt. Edmund Williams hail'd Captain Ambrose , and asked why he did not bear down nearer; that he saw a great many Guns fired by the Rupert ; that the Marlbro's Masts went away, and the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal-Oak , might have gone down to her Assistance, but did not.
dialogueText.dialogue: Is this Deposition true?
Yes.
Did the Rupert bring up to windward of the Line of the Namur and Marlbro' ?
Yes.
Did you see her engage?
Yes.
With what Ship?
The Ship a-stern of the Hercules , she had none to engage at first.
Was she within point-blank?
No.
Was she in a Line with the Admiral?
No.
Did you see the Marlbro' when her Masts went away?
I saw her about that time.
Where was the Rupert then?
A little to windward of us.
Did she bear away to assist the Marlbro' ?
I know not that she did.
Did you see the Fireship going down?
I saw her before she blew up.
Did you ever see the Rupert properly engaged?
No.
Was the Rupert ever in the Line?
About four.
What were the Words Captain Williams made use of, when he hailed the Rupert ?
He asked why he would not bear down, but can't tell whether there was any Answer.
Was it the Captain himself that hail'd Captain Ambrose ?
Yes.
Were the Words, if he would bear down, or why he would not bear down?
Why he would not bear down.
Did you ever see the Rupert , while you was engaged, engage at a proper Distance to do Execution?
No.
As you did not hear any Answer, did the Rupert bear away upon your hailing?
I cannot tell.
Did not the Rupert bear away when the Royal-Oak did?
I cannot tell.
At the Evening when the Signal of Battle was hauled down, were any of the Spanish Ships past by the Rupert ?
I do not remember any of them past the Rupert .
Do you believe the Rupert bore down when the Royal-Oak did?
No.
Was it in the Rupert's Power to engage those Ships?
Yes.
Must she have gone to leeward of the Line, if she had gone at a proper Distance to engage them?
Yes.
What time of the Day did your first bring up?
About Two.
Where was the Rupert then?
Close to us.
How near you?
Within a Stone's throw.
How long did you engage them?
Three quarters of an Hour.
When you left off, where was the Rupert ?
We were very near her then.
Did not the Rupert engage then?
I did not see she did.
Where was the Enemy off you then?
That Ship was a-breast off us.
Had the Rupert a Ship to engage with then?
No.
When you left off engaging, how far was the Rupert from you?
A little way the first time.
Was it after you left off engaging, you hailed the Rupert ?
Yes.
Did you make Sail after the Rupert then?
No, we lay still.
Was it after you left off firing the first time, that you hauled up to the Rupert ?
No, after we had engaged the four Ships.
Did not you hail the Rupert ?
Yes.
At what time?
At Three.
Was it after engaging the first Ship?
Yes.
Did not you haul up to the Rupert after engaging the first Ship?
No, it was after engaging the four Ships.
Was the Rupert close by you when you engaged the first Ships?
Yes.
As the Enemy shot a-head, did not the Rupert engage her?
I cannot tell.
Was you near enough when you engaged the single Ship?
No.
Was the Rupert ever to leeward of you?
Not till we wore.
Was she ever right a-head of you?
No, rather upon our Weather-Bow, if any thing.
When you haul'd off from the four of the Enemy's Ships, did you hail the Rupert ?
We did hail her, but I can't be certain whether it was after we had done engaging the first Ship, or after engaging the four Ships.
Did you ever observe the Spanish Ships to shorten Sail, or alter their Course from your first engaging them?
No.
dialogueText.nonSpeech:
James Patterson , Master's Mate of the Royal-Oak , was called in and sworn. His Deposition read, setting forth, that he was Master's Mate of the Royal-Oak on the 11th of February 1743; that about one, the Admiral and Marlbro' bore down and engaged the Enemy; and that the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal-Oak bore down also, but not so near as the Admiral and Marlbro' did, and that they might have gone nearer, having Wind sufficient. That the Marlbro' was disabled, having her Main and Mizen-Masts shot away, and the Namur was then engaged in Fight, and the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and
Royal-Oak were then to windward, and might have assisted the Marlbro' , but did not; that between three and four, the Ann Galley Fireship bore down upon the Enemy, but she was not covered or conducted by any of the other Ships, and that the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and Royal-Oak , might have covered her, but none of them did.
dialogueText.dialogue: Where was you quartered?
Upon the Fore-castle.
What do you know concerning the Rupert ?
When the Admiral bore down we bore down, but the Admiral took a shorter round than we did, and when we brought to first, the Rupert was to windward of us, and she brought-to before we did.
Did you engage a single Ship at first?
Yes.
At what time did you begin?
I can't remember the time of the Day, it was about half an hour after the Admiral began.
Where was the Rupert ?
Upon our Larboard-Bow.
At what distance from you?
A Cable's Length.
Did she engage that Ship too?
Not immediately, she fired some time after we did, but can't say at what Ship.
Where was the Rupert when you had done engaging the single Ship?
Upon our Larboard-Bow.
How near you?
Pretty near us, we hauled up, and came close to her Quarter.
Did not you hail the Rupert then?
I cannot say positively, whether it was before or after we bore down the last time.
How long did you lye there?
Half an Hour.
What did the Rupert do afterwards?
She did not bear down with us.
What past in your hailing the Rupert ?

Our Captain hailed several times, then Captain Ambrose came into his Starboard-Gallery; our Captain asked why they did not bear down nearer? Captain Ambrose turn'd round, but said nothing that I heard.
Do you think that Captain Ambrose was then within Gun-shot of the Enemy?
Within random Shot he might.
Repeat the Words that past on your hailing.

When our Captain hailed, Captain Ambrose came into his Starboard-Gallery, he said, what do you say? Captain Williams said, Why don't you edge nearer, Captain Ambrose ? or Words to that effect. Captain Ambrose turn'd round, and went out of his Gallery into his Cabin.
When you hailed the Rupert did she bear down?
No.
Did you hear Captain Ambrose's Words distinctly, What do you say, Captain Williams ?
Yes.
When you were engaging the four Ships, was Captain Ambrose within a proper Distance of the Enemy?
I believe not.
Or was he at any part of the Time during the Engagement within Point-blank?
No.
After you hailed the Rupert , did the Royal-Oak bear down singly?
I can't tell whether it was after or before hailing, that we bore down singly.
Was you ever hail'd by Captain Ambrose ?
Not that I ever heard of.
Must you have heard it, if he had hailed you?
Yes, I was upon the Fore-castle all Day.
Was the Rupert within Point-blank, or in a Line with the Namur and Marlbro' , when she fired?
No.
Which of the four Sail of the Enemy were you engaged with the last time?
Most of the four.
How far did the Headmost shoot a-head of you, before the Admiral made the Signal to leave off Chace and wore?
I don't remember whether she was before our Beam or not; if she was before our Beam, it was as much as she was.
What Sail did they come up with?
Top-gallant-sails, Top-sails, and Fore-sails; some had their Top-gallant-sails down, and some not.
Did they shorten Sail, or alter their Course upon your firing?
I don't remember they did, they edged away a little more.
Was it from your fire?
No.
How was the Rupert from you then?
To windward of us.
What was she doing?
I can't tell.
How far to windward of you?
A Cable's length upon our Bow.
Did you see the Rupert fire then?
Yes.
At what Ship?
I can't say.
Was she wide upon your Bow?
A Point and a Half or two Points upon our weather Bow?
Was the Rupert ever within Point-blank?
I believe not till we wore in the Evening.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
Yes.
Which was nearest the Fireship, the five Sail of the Enemy, or the Rupert ?
The Rupert was the nearest when the Fireship was coming down.
Which was the nearest when she blew up?
The Spanish Ships.
Which of our Ships was the nearest?
The Rupert .
How did the Fireship bear from you?
Upon our Starboard-bow.
How did the Fireship bear from the Spanish Ships?
The headmost of them was abaft her Beam.
Did you see the Marlborough when she lost her Masts?
Yes.
Did the Rupert assist her?
No.
When you engaged the four Ships, how were they from you?
The two sternmost upon our Quarter, and the two headmost upon our Beam.
How did these Ships come up, with the Wind large?
Two or three Points from the Wind.
How cou'd I have engaged those Ships till they came a-head of the Royal Oak ?
You cou'd not.
Were those Ships in a Line with their Admiral?
Them seem'd to come up to close the Line with their Admiral.
Were they in a Line with their Admiral?
The Admiral was further to windward than they.
Did they come up as you did?
They edg'd away more than we did.
If Captain Williams and I had bore away further than we did, before we brought up, wou'd not those Ships have shot us away to leeward of them?
Had we gone down as close as the Admiral and Marlbro' did, if those Ships had had a Mind, some, if not all of them might have weatherd us.
Where did the Single Ship go to that you engaged?
I can't tell.
It is very odd, if you engaged a Ship an Hour, that you don't know where she went to; pray recollect your-self.
I know there was a Single Ship distant from the four which we engaged.
Did I engage as soon as I had any Ship to engage with?
I don't remember what Ship you engaged with, I saw you fire.
Did you ever see me haul off from the Enemy or endeavour to get nearer?
I never saw you endeavour to get nearer from your first hauling up.
Did I haul off?
You seem'd to keep the same Position.
Where was the Shot that you receiv'd in your Main Mast, was it the Aftermost part or one Side?
Between the two Cheeks in the Aftermost part.
Did not that Shot come from the Ship a-stern of you?
It was either from the sternmost of the Enemy, or that next to her as I believe, I am not positive.
How cou'd I get between them to fire upon them till they got out of the Way?
I don't know whether we did not receive that Shot in the hauling off, we might receive it then.
Upon your hauling off did you get your Fore-Tack on board, haul your Mizen out, and haul your Wind till you got to windward of my weather Beam?
I do not remember we got our Weather-Tack aboard till we wore.
Did you ever see me yaw Ship, put my Sails a-back in order to open the Enemy's Ships, and bring my weather Guns to bear?
I saw you once bring to.
Did I ever fire my weather Guns?
I can't say you did.
Did you ever see me yaw Ship, put the Helm sometime Port, sometime Starboard, and lay my Sails back?
I did not observe you did.
How long did you fire before I began?
Some time; I can't remember how long.
As these Ships were under their Topsails, Topgallant sails and Foresails, they must have soon pass'd you; did I not engage them then?
I can't say; the headmost just came before our Beam, I saw her firing.
Did you see any of her Shot fall short?
Yes, and several of your Shot fell short of her.
How far was I from the Enemy when you saw me fire?
Less than a Mile.
Was I within a Cable's Length of you?
Yes.
Was the Rupert and Royal Oak in a Line with the Fireship when she blew up?
No.
How far was the Fireship to Leeward of them?
About half a Mile.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Q.
dialogueText.dialogue: Did any of the sternmost Ships of the Enemy ever pass the Rupert ?
No, I saw none pass till we wore.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Q.
dialogueText.dialogue: What side of the Deck did Captain Williams stand on when he hail'd the Rupert ?
Upon the Weather side of the Quarter-Deck.
dialogueText.nonSpeech: Then Captain Philip Toms , late of the Norfolk , call'd in, and sworn, and his Deposition read, setting forth, that he was second Lieutenant of the Norfolk on the 11th of February 1743, that about eleven the Signal was made to engage; that about half past twelve the Admiral and Marlbro' began to fire upon the Enemy; that all the Captains a-stern of the Marlbro' were in Sight of the Signal to engage, and of the Engagement; that the Fireship bore down near the Dorsetshire , Rupert , and the Royal Oak , that she was not cover'd or conducted by any of the other Ships, and that those three Ships might have cover'd her, but neither of them did, and she blew up without Effect. Then the Court desired him to relate what he knew concerning the Rupert .
dialogueText.dialogue:
All I know of her is, that the three Ships a-stern of the Marlbro' made an Angle to windward of the Line, the Dorsetshire was the leewardmost, the Essex to windward of her, the Rupert to leeward of the Essex ; I did not see them till after two, when the
Marlboro' was out of Action; I did not see any thing more.
When the Royal Oak engaged, how did the Rupert bear from her?
I can't tell.
Did you see the Marlborough when her Masts fell?
Yes.
Did you see the Rupert , or any of the other Ships a-stern, assist her?
No, they all then made the Angle, and were in the Position I mentioned.
Were they firing then?
I saw them firing once, but can't tell whether it was then or no.
Did you see the Fireship go down?
Yes.
Did you see her blow up?
No, but I saw her Combustibles in the Air.
Did any of those Ships go down with her?
I did not see any of them go down with her, but they went down after her.
How long after her?
The Admiral was wearing then, and they all bore down with him.
When you saw the Royal Oak to leeward of the other Ships, was the Rupert disabled, or what was the Reason she did not bear down?
I can't say what might be the Reason.
Was there Wind enough?
Yes.
When the Royal Oak was engaging the second Ship a-stern of the Spanish Admiral, where were the other Spanish Ships?
A long Way a-stern, and to Windward of every Ship of Admiral Mathews's Division.
Are you sure of that?
Yes, it is plain they were to Windward, because I was to Leeward of the Dorsetshire , Essex , Rupert and Royal Oak , and I saw those Ships to Windward of them.
SOURCE TEXT: A. At what time?
At two, and half past two, and at three: Admiral Lestock's Division engaged them to windward of our Line at three, and when Mr. Lestock's Division neared them, they edged away towards their Admiral.
Was Mr. Lestock's Division to windward of the Admiral's?
Yes.
